Henry's Hurrah!.EventDesc:
Join us for an Oktoberfest-themed celebration in honor of Henry Melchior Muhlenberg's birthday -- 308(!) years after Henry was born. Enjoy birthday treats (including an ice cream float bar, cupcakes, and caramel apple dippers) and refreshments, plus an Oktoberfest-themed Mobile Mule. In addition, look forward to a Henry-themed photo booth; giant chess game; DJ; live performances by the Pep Band; and more!

ATTENTION STUDENTS! Custom "Henry's Hurrah!" pub mugs, tie dye t-shirts, and tech stickers are available to the first 200 attendees!

Study Abroad Information & Poster Fair.EventDesc:
Do you think you might be interested in studying abroad next academic year (Fall 2020 or Spring 2021)? Attend the Study Abroad Information & Poster Fair on September 11th, anytime from 10am - 3pm in Seegers 111-113!
 Pick up the approved program list of over 160 different short- and long-term study abroad options;
 Speak with program, student, and faculty representatives;
 See students' posters about their experience; and
 Begin mentally preparing for the study abroad application deadline in December 2019.
 If you are an athlete, learn how you can continue your off-season workout regimen while abroad.

First year students, Sophomores, and Juniors are welcome to attend, as are Faculty and Staff!

Flint's Deadly Water.EventDesc: This free documentary screening of a new PBS FRONTLINE investigation, Flints Deadly Water, is the result of two years of on-the-ground reporting to examine the true toll of the Flint water crisis. "What they found reveals how a public health disaster thats become known forthe lead poisoning of thousands of children also spawned one of the largestoutbreaks of Legionnaires disease in U.S. history. The screening will be followed by a Q&A with several of the participants in the documentary.

Ieva Jusionyte: \"Injury and Rescue on t.EventDesc: Ieva Jusionyte is assistant professor of anthropology and social studies at Harvard University. Her research and teaching interests lie at the intersection of political-legal and medical anthropology, with a focus on the study of state power and the materiality of violence; law and criminalized livelihoods; discourses and infrastructures of security; technologies of injury; politics and ethics of representation; and ethnography as method and storytelling.

Study Abroad Information Meeting: SAI Pr.EventDesc: Information meeting for students interested in studying abroad next year in Italy at one of the SAI Study Abroad Programs in Florence, Rome, Siena, or Milan. The Vice President for Academic Affairs at SAI Programs will discuss the programs and student services available at the different SAI locations in Italy, including the academics and special certificate programs, housing options, city life, internship opportunities, & SAI excursions.

A Career in Public Health Service.EventDesc: Epidemiologist Nakia S. Clemmons, MPH, REHS Lieutenant, US Public Health Service, will give a presentation by video conference on her career in public health service.Among other highlights, she will describe her work with the U.S. Army's Public Health Command and her investigation of the 2015 Disneyland measles outbreak for the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. She will also participate in a Q&A with students regarding possible career paths in public health service.

INTO THE WOODS.EventDesc: on a custom schedule. Click here to see the series dates.

Amy-Jill Levine: \"On Different Grounds:.EventDesc: A.-J. Levine is university professor of New Testament and Jewish studies, Mary Jane Werthan Professor of Jewish Studies and professor of New Testament studies at Vanderbilt Divinity School and College of Arts and Science. She is an internationally prominent public speaker on Christian-Jewish relations, an instructor in the Great Courses series and a consultant to the Vatican and the World Council of Churches. Her books include The Misunderstood Jew: The Church and the Scandal of the Jewish Jesus and Short Stories by Jesus: The Enigmatic Parables of a Controversial Rabbi. She is the co-editor, with Marc Z. Brettler, of the Jewish Annotated New Testament.

Meeting on 10/31 for First Year students to learn about Muhlenberg's general study abroad process, the types of study abroad programs available, the courses they should or should not take abroad, and how they should apply during their Sophomore year.

Conflict Without Contempt.EventDesc: Conflict is often presented as a negative experience to avoid, and yet conflict is a part of every persons life. What can we discover about ourselves and others when we reframe conflict as an opportunity for learning, relationship building, social justice and creativity? This talk will focus on ways to re-think conflict, through the lens of Gandhi and King as well as through the frameworks of systems thinking and restorative justice.

Posadas.EventDesc: Posadas will take place on Tuesday 3 December from 7-8:30 pm. We will start at the CA, then move on to Seegers, then on to the Chaplain's house, then end up at the President's house, with Latin holiday treats at our last two stops, generously funded by the President's office. What are Posadas? They are a song cycle from 16th century Mexico. They are similar to carols, in that a group of singers moves from one home to another.Posadas they are different in that they follow the Advent story of the refugee family of Mary and Joseph as they travel through foreign lands in search of a place where Mary can have here child --that would be the baby Jesus!-- in safety and whatever comfort they can find. The songs recount the pleas for shelter, the rejection that followed, and eventually, the welcoming of this migrant family. Por supuesto, this is a powerful reminder of today's situation of migrants crossing borders and facing hostility... with a happy ending that we hope will inspire us all. Plus, the music is truly lovely.   Please mention this to your students, put it on your calendars... we will have a time set before the 3rd to practice... though practice is NOT required for this to be a success.
Posadas.Location: Muhlenberg College:  Chew Street  (View Map)2400 Chew Street Allentown, PA 18104

Accessibility and Technology.EventDesc: Join us for a mini workshop on accessibility and technology, and in collaboration time on works in progress. Both faculty and staff are welcome to learn about tools, tips, and techniques for maximizing inclusive design and course materials, publicity, document creation and the like, with particular focus on technology's roles and options. Leave with a start on your course updates, ideas on how to adjust current workflows and documents, and develop pathways forward, all with knowledge of how technology and best practices related to accessibility can help!

Collaboration Tools.EventDesc: Wanting to try something new this spring with your courses? Aiming for more collaboration inside and outside the classroom? Want to scale-up your technological tool knowledge and use? This Zoom session will explore options here at Muhlenberg as well as some things to keep in mind while considering additional collaborative tools and their possible use.
